editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

list.head: The actors names.
list.item: Sir William admirer, and many other gentlemen.

div.head: Scene 1.
div.stage: Enter a company of young gentlemen, and two or three young ladies, as the lady Gadder, the lady Kindeling, and the lady Bridlehead.

sp.speaker: Kindeling.
sp.p: My dear Gadder.

sp.speaker: Gadder.
sp.p: My sweet kindling.

div.stage: They embrace and kiss each other.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: Faith lady's nature never made women to kiss each other, and therefore 'tis unnatural, and being unnatural it is unlawful, and being unlawful it ought to be forbidden.

sp.speaker: Gadder.
sp.p: Yes, you would have us kiss you men.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: No ladies, we men will kiss you women, if you please to give us leave.

sp.speaker: Bridlehead.
sp.p: You will take leave sometimes.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: 'Tis when we think we shall not be refused, or at least not to be disfavoured for it.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: What, kissing again? faith ladies you will make us believe by your often kissing, that you desire we should kiss you, and with that belief we may run into an error, if it be an error to kiss a fair lady.

sp.speaker: Kindling.
sp.p: Fie, fie, you men are odd creatures.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: No, you women are odd creatures, when you are not with us men.

sp.speaker: Kindling.
sp.p: Prithee Gadder and Bridlehead let us go do something to pass away our time.

sp.speaker: Gadder.
sp.p: What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Bridlehead.
sp.p: Let us go to cards.

sp.speaker: Gadder.
sp.p: Faith I have made a vow not to play for money.

sp.speaker: Bridlehead.
sp.p: We will play for sweetmeats.

sp.speaker: Kindling.
sp.p: No, prithee let us play for a sack posset.

sp.speaker: Gadder.
sp.p: O no, we will play for sweetmeats.

sp.speaker: Kindling.
sp.p: I say a sack posset.

sp.speaker: Gadder.
sp.p: Let the most voices carry it.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: I will speak for the men, we say a sack posset, for that will make us both good company in the eating the posset, and after 'tis eaten, whereas sweetmeats will make us heavy and dull.

sp.speaker: Gadder.
sp.p: Well then let us go play for a sack posset.

sp.speaker: Bridlehead.
sp.p: Faith a sack posset will make me drunk.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: You will be the better company lady.

sp.speaker: Kindling.
sp.p: Fie Bridlehead, you should not say drunk, but your head giddy.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: That is better than to be drunk: for a giddy head hath a light heel.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: The lord poverty is a gallant noble person.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: They are gallant and noble that are rich, and titled honour without means, is like a body without a soul.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: You are mistaken friend, it is rather a soul without a body.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Alas titled honour without means to maintain it, is despised.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: If the person hath merit worthy of his titled honour, that titled honour is worthy to be respected and bowed to by all inferior persons; nay put the case that honourable titles are placed upon unworthy persons, yet all ought to give respect to those titles, and to do homage thereunto, though not unto the person, yet because it comes from a lawful and supreme power; as natural rays of light do from the sun; and those that strive through envy and through spite, for to eclipse the light, deserve to be in a perpetual darkness; so those that do detract from titled honours, ought never to be honoured with titles or respect.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Why, 'tis not only I that have no such titles of honour that speaks against them, but those that do possess them, and their forefathers long before them.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p:
They that do so ought to be degraded, as being unworthy to wear the badge or mark of their forefather's merits, or heroic acts, for they do show they have none of their own; but those that get their own honours, by their own merits and worthy actions, deserve them best; for they, like as a clear and glorious day, appear; for oft-times their posterity, like clouds begotten from gross and drowsy earth, strive to quench out their fathers flaming honours, and by their baseness obscure the light of their forefathers great and glorious fame, and in the end bury themselves in dark oblivion, as vanishing to nothing, as being never mentioned nor remembered; but those that for their loyalty and their fidelity unto their King and country, have hazarded lives, and lost their liberties and estates, and are grown poor for honesty's sake, and virtuous causes, yet they in after ages will live with great renown; for 'tis not in the power of spite to pull them down; for the gods give fame to noble actions, as Kings give titled honours; though men that are base will not relieve them, yet fame will remember them; and though base men will rail against them, yet fame will praise them; and though they die with poverty, and should end their lives in a foul
ditch, yet shall that ditch be honoured by their death, more than the rich unworthy man be honoured by his stately tombs and costly funerals.

div.head: Scene 3.
div.stage: Enter the lady solitary, and the lady examination.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: What's the matter with you today lady solitary? you look as if you were in a married humour.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: Why lady examination, what humour is a married humour?

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: Why a mass of ill humours mixed or put together; as a lumpish, dumpish, dull, stupid humour; or a peevish, fretting, pining, whining humour; or a brawling, yawling, quarrelling, scolding humour; or a jealous, suspicious humour; or a fawning, feigning, dissembling humour.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: If these humours are woven into the marriage knot, I will never marry, for I would be loath to have the peace of my life strangled in discontent: for whosoever be subject to these humours can never be happy.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: You will change your mind, and rather live with these humours than without a husband; but I am come now to fetch you abroad, for their is a company of sociable ladies and gallants, that have made a meeting some league of, where there will be mirth, jollity, plenty and pleasure, and they desire you will be sociable for once, and go along with them.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: Would you have the body which is the habitation of the mind a wanderer, travelling from place to place, disturbing the mind with unprofitable journeys?

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: No, I would have it remove so as it may always situate itself in a wholesome, profitable, plentiful, pleasant, and pleasurable place.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: I perceive you prefer the pleasures of the body before the delight of the mind.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: Why the mind can take no delight without the body; for the body gives the mind a being and habitation: for there would be no mind if there were nobody , but if there could be a mind without a body, yet the mind could receive no delight without the pleasure of the body, for the pleasure of the body is the delight of the mind, and not the delight of the mind the pleasure of the body, for the mind doth never give nor return; wherefore come away, and leave your solitary musing to those whose condition of fortune denies them the use of the world, and worldly pleasures, and do not deny yourself, for I hate a self-denying creature.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: Well, you shall prevail with me for this one time.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Have you seen monsieur Thesis book of poems that is newly come forth?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: And how do you approve of them?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: As well as I do of an anagram.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: There is never an anagram in the book.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Why the whole book is an anagram of doctor Costives poems: for he hath only new placed the words, as they do anagrams of names, but the whole matter, sense, and conceits is the same.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Indeed he hath imitated him.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: By your favour, imitation is only to be like another, and not the same; but his is the very same, as I have told you, for which he deserves less praises than a imitator, although those that do imitate any excellent poet, do not gain so much honour to themselves, as they give honour to those they imitate; as for example, the imitators of Homer give more honour to Homer than to themselves; for imitators are only as painters, where he that is imitated is as nature, or the gods, for the one draws but copies, the other makes the original; so that there is as much difference as a man, and the picture of a man.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: But a painter that draws the picture of a man, very like the life, he may be more famous than the man that is drawn.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: But not worshipped and adored, as nature is, that made him: for art cannot outdo nature, nor do as nature hath dove, and doth do; and an imitator is but an artificer, whenas the original author is a creator, and ought to be accounted of, and respected, and worshipped as divine; but there are or have been but very few poets that have such powers and parts to make a perfect creature, which is a perfect work, as poems, scenes, or story; but some poets are like chemist, that strive and labour to make as nature makes, but most fail in their work, and lose their labours, wanting that natural heat, or well-tempered matter, which should produce such creatures as nature makes, yet some 'tis said have made gold, as Raimond Lully.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Then Homer is a Raimond Lully in poetry.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Nay rather Raimond Lully is a Homer in chemistry: for no man ought to compare Homer to any creature, by reason he hath outwrought nature, having done that which she never did; for nature never made gods, devils, hells, and heavens, as Homer hath done.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: For my part I had rather be Raimond Lully than Homer: for I had rather have the art to make gold, than the nature to make poems.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: You would not gain so much by gold as wit.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Why, what shall I gain?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Fame.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: But gold will bribe fame to speak as I would have her, if I have golded enough to bribe her.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: But poems will force fame to speak for you without a bribe.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: That were all one to me, so she speaks well, whether she be forced, flattered, or bribed.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: But there is a fate of poverty on chemists, as much as on poets, so that if you were as excellent a chemist as Raimond Lully, you would be as poor as divine Homer.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Not if I could make gold.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Yes, for chemists spend more in the making of gold, than they gain by it when it is made; and how should they do otherways, when they must needs spend a pound or pounds to make a grain? for the limbeck of a chemist is but a little still set a-work by a wasting fire, whereas nature's limbeck is the earth, set a-work by an undecayable fire, which is the sun; this chemist becomes as poor by an overgreedy covetousness, as poets by a despising carelessness.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Then chemists are like those bodies which become lean with overeating, and poets like those bodies that becomes lean by overfasting; the one surfeits, the other famishes.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Indeed chemists are so greedily covetous, and feed so much on hopes, as they never leave until such time as they have vomited out all their wealth, and then they become sick and lean with poverty.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: The lady faction is of a strange busy nature, she runs into every house, takes upon her to govern every ones family, yet cannot rule her own; she condemns all actions, be they never so just or prudent; all officers, be they never so worthy, or fitly placed; all laws, be they never so beneficial, or expedient for the commonwealth; all customs, be they never so ancient or harmless, indeed all peaceable, wise, and well ordered governments: she hates and delights in nothing but disordered change.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: 'Tis said she is in love with sir William admirer.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: And he in love with the lady peaceable.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: She is a sweet lady.

div.head: Scene 6.
div.stage: Enter the lady peaceable, and sir William admirer.

sp.speaker: Admirer.
sp.p: I will sit and listen to what you say, and learn from you what is the noblest way to entertain the life.

sp.speaker: Peaceable.
sp.p:
Alas I cannot learn you, I have not long experience, my soul is
young, a mere novice soul, it wants both growth and experienced years, for I am like a house that is newly built and is unfurnished.

sp.speaker: Admirer.
sp.p: Though you are young, you are wise.

sp.speaker: Peaceable.
sp.p: How can you expect youth can be discreet and wise, when those that have lived long, and have had much experience, are oftentimes fools? wherefore I can only entertain you like a parrot, only with words, not wisely to discourse, and if you should listen to me long, I shall surfeit your ears with idle words, for the brain will be as soon overcharged with noise, as the stomach with meat.

sp.speaker: Admirer.
sp.p: I can no more be weary of thy words, than angels are with heavenly music.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Lady peaceable, the report is you are ambitious to get away my servant sir William admirer from me.

sp.speaker: Peaceable.
sp.p: I am only ambitious to live virtuously, and die piously.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Why servant, I hear you have forsaken me.

sp.speaker: Admirer.
sp.p: I despaired of ever being entertained, and so I never really addressed a suit, but by way of raillery.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Your mistress doth not believe you, for she blushes either for your faults, or her own.

sp.speaker: Peaceable.
sp.p: My bashfulness proceeds not from a guiltiness, either of base actions, wicked thoughts, mean birth, or breeding, or evil or erroneous opinions; for my bashfulness is only an effect of nature: for as some are naturally fearful, so am I naturally bashful; and as melancholy produces a sad countenance, so bashfulness produceth an extorted and a convulsive countenance; as grief produces tears, so bashfulness produces blushing.

sp.speaker: Admirer.
sp.p: Lady faction, spare my young mistress, lest she should outrun you in a full speed.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Your mistress is too grave, and speaks too scholastical for a woman, she seems as if she had been bred in an university, which breeding is fitter for a man.

sp.speaker: Peaceable.
sp.p: No surely, for men should be bred with heroic actions, women with modest contemplations, as I have been.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: If you have talked so seldom, and have learned so little, how come you to know so much?

sp.speaker: Peaceable.
sp.p: My knowledge is not copious, yet I have learned as much as my years could embrace, and my desire is to know as much as modesty will allow of, honour will give leave to, capacity can comprehend, or life can reach at; but the longest life is but a short time to gather knowledge in; but madam, I should think I had learned well, if I knew how to do you service.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Let me tell you, 'tis craft and subtlety that you practice, to catch fond, facile fools under the veil of civility, but not good nature; for you, like a sorceress as you are, enchant and bewitch all that come near you, with this dissembling, for which you ought to be banished from all noble company.

sp.speaker: Peaceable.
sp.p: Take heed lady of sharp-headed curses, that shoot through innocent lips, they seldom miss the mark they aim at.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Shoot as many as you will, I fear them not.

sp.speaker: Admirer.
sp.p: My dear sweet, wife, virtuous mistress, be not angry, for all the world knows the lady faction is a disturber of all good and peaceable society.

sp.speaker: Peaceable.
sp.p: No, I am not angry with her, but I will watch her, lest she should do me some harm.

div.head: Scene 7.
div.stage: Enter the lady solitary as sitting a writing, then enter the lady examination as to visit her.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: Prithee what art thou writing?

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: I am writing fancies.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: Prithee what are fancies?

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: Why, fancies are minced objects, pounded and chopped by imagination, which imaginations are the several cooks which serve the mind, and as skilful cooks of several meats make bisks or olioes, so doth the imagination of several objects; and as skilful cooks will mix several meats, so as not any one particular shall be tasted, so doth the imagination of several objects or subjects.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: But some say fancies are created by motion in the brain, which would be there were there no such materials as objects or subjects, which the senses as caterers bring in.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: The brain can no more create fancy without the materials of outward objects, and subjects, than nature can create a world without matter to make it withal; so the brain can no more create fancy without the help of the senses, than nature can create a creator without the help of motion; for though fancies are the works of the brain, yet the brain could not work unless it had something to work on; but objects and subjects of objects, may be divided in the brain so small, or beaten so thin, as the first form may be beaten out, and when the first form is gone, we deny the matter, like as if we should deny that paper is made with rags, because the form of rags is beaten out; thus by the subtle and curious motion of proud conception joined with the dazzled memory, we deny the senses a share, as not being partners therein, or labours thereof, the same way we conceive the gods, for the conceptions of the gods is but minzed imaginations.

div.head: Scene 8.
div.stage: Enter the lady censurer, and the lady examination.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: Lady censurer, pray what think you of the lady retorts wit, hath not she a great wit?

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: O fie, she hath a chambermaid's wit.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: What wit is that lady?

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: Why a snip-snaply wit.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: Indeed I have heard many nursery maids give so sharp and quick replies, as amongst some would be judged to be great wits, yet come to discourse seriously with them, and they were not much wiser than beasts; but what do you think of the lady sharps wit?

sp.speaker: Censurer
sp.p: Her wit fetches the skin off of the ears, it corrodes the minds of the hearers, more than vinegar the tongues of the tasters.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: How approve you of the lady Courtlyes wit?

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: Her wit is tedious, as all complementing wits are, they tire the ears of the hearers.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: What say you to the lady Strongline's wit?

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: Her wit is costive, and is delivered with labour, difficulty, and pain.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: What think you of the lady learning's wit?

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: Her wit is an alms tub, it yields nothing but scraps, fragments, and broken pieces.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: What think you of the lady subtleties wit?

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: Her wit is lime, twigs, snares and traps to catch fools in or with.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: How like you the lady fancies wit?

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: Her wit indeed is a true natural wit, it 'tis sweet and delightful, easy and pleasing, as being free and unconstrained.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: How like you the lady contemplation's wit?

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: Her wit is wise, and distinguishing well: for all comtemplative persons judge, weigh, and measure out the right and truth of every thing, and find out the easiest and profitablest ways, by the help of consideration; yet contemplative persons when they come into company, or public societies, their tongues do as boys, that having been kept hard to their studies, when once they get a play day, they run wildly about, and many times do extravagant actions: so contemplative persons when they are in company their tongues speak extravagant words, and their behaviour for the most part is unnatural to their dispositions; but of all wits the contemplative wit is the best, by reason it is a near neighbour to poetry.

div.head: Scene 9.
div.stage: Enter the lady Gadder, the lady Kindeling, and the lady Bridlehead.

sp.speaker: Gadder.
sp.p: Come friend kindling, and friend Bridlehead, let us go to the lady censurers; for there is the resort of all the gallants at her house.

sp.speaker: Bridlehead.
sp.p: What should we do there? for all the men will hearken so much to her discourse, as they will take no notice of us.

sp.speaker: Kindling.
sp.p: Why then we will take notice of them: for if we should stay at home, and not seek out the company of men, faith we shall never get us husbands.

sp.speaker: Bridlehead.
sp.p: It is easy to get the company of men, not so easy to get husbands: for we have a great many men that come often to visit us, but none offer to marry us.

sp.speaker: Gadder.
sp.p: But the more acquaintance we have, the more likely we should get husbands; for it were a hard: fortune, if amongst so many men we should not get one husband.

sp.speaker: Kindling.
sp.p: Why one husband will not serve us three.

sp.speaker: Gadder.
sp.p: I mean each of us one.

sp.speaker: Bridlehead.
sp.p: Well then let us go.

div.head: Scene 10.
div.stage: Enter the lady solitary, and the lady examination.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: O thou clod of earth, sit not idle here, but go abroad and receive the comfort of the sun, which works to all effects.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: I need not, for my mind is as the sun itself, and hath the same effects; for my mind doth contract, attract, dilates, and expulses, for sometimes it dilates itself as the sun doth, in beams of light, which is inventions, at other times the mind dilates, as the sun his hair, which is in poetic flames, and in rarified fancies; likewise the mind attracts, as the sun doth vapours from the earth, so my mind attracts knowledge from the world, as from several subjects and objects, as the sun from several climates; likewise as the sun contracts porous matter into a solid substance, so doth my mind contract loose thoughts into solid judgement; and as the sun expulses united bodies into parts, so doth my mind expulse its serious contemplations, and united conceptions into several discourses.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: Prithee expulse this discourse amongst thy sociable friends.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: What amongst the sociable virgins?

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: Nay faith, wives for the most part are more sociable than maids.

div.head: Scene 11.
div.stage: Enter the lady censurer, and a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: Sir, I hear you intend to be a soldier in the wars.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: Yes madam, I am come to take my leave, and to kiss your ladyship's hands before I go.

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: Sir you have chosen an honourable profession, for though it is an industrious, careful, painful, and dangerous profession, yet it is a noble protection to the weak and infirm, to the decrepit age, and shiftless youth; to the faint and tender female sex; it is a guard to the ashes of the dead, and to the temples of the gods; for without marshal discipline no peace would be kept, truth and right would be torn from the owners, justice pulled out from her seat, and monarchy quite from his throne, and though a soldier may lose his life sooner than nature did determine, yet in recompense, honour buries him, and fame builds up his monument.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: Your descriptions madam are able to make a coward a valiant man.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Some have thought the world was but as stage, and that the several creatures are the several actors, and that every several generation is a new play.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: No every several generation doth not seem as if they were new plays; for there seems to be but one play, and that to continue to the end of the world, and that every generation seems only new actors, that play over the same parts, for we well perceive that the following generations act but what the former generations did before them; 'tis true the world seems to be the stage, and the seas, rocks, rivers, plants, hills, dales, cities, towns, villages, and the like, are as the several changes, the animals as the several actors, the several seasons the several scenes, and the spectators are the gods, and the end of the world the end of the play, and then they must make another world, if they will have another play.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Surely Mercury is their poet.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: 'Tis very likely, also 'tis probable Pallas helps him.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Nay 'tis probable that Venus and Cupid helps him, for love and beauty doth at all times assist a poet.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p:
There is no excellent and extraordinary wit, but hath many assistants,
as first nature is the chief; so likewise Mercury, Pallas, Venus, Cupid, and the Muses.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: The most foolish actors of all actors, are women.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: The truth is, it 'tis very unhappy for women, that they are not instructed in the rules rhetoric, by reason they talk so much, that they might talk sensibly, whereas now for want of that art, they talk mere nonsense.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: But all women are apt to speak more than to act, by reason words are easily spoke, and deeds so hard to be done.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Faith women are as full of actions as words; for all their life is employed with talking and running about to no purpose.

div.head: Scene 13.
div.stage: Enter the lady solitary, the lady examination, the lady censurer, and a grave matron.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: Come let, us go abroad, for I love to refresh myself in the serene air, taking the pleasure of every season, as when the returning sun spins golden beams, which interweaves into the thinner air, as golden threads with softer silk, making it like a mantle, rich and warm, which wraps the body of each creature in; so in the summer when lifferous winds do fan the sultry heat; then in the autumn that's like a temperate bath, which is neither too hot nor too cold; then in the winter, when freezing cold doth purge the air, as physic doth the body from most corrupt humours, and binds each loose deshevered part.

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: The winter will bind up your active limbs, and numb your flesh, and make your spirits chill, besides winter doth bedrid nature, the spiteful malicious and wicked season, for it doth strive for to destroy each several thing, and it yields nothing good itself; besides it doth imprison many things, binding them fast with icy chains, taking away their natural liberty, also it doth not only frown, and lour on the bright sun, making his light dim and dusky, but winter doth untwist, and doth unweave the sun's bright golden beams, and wind them on dark bottoms.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: The cold sharp air is as sharp unto the touch, as a lemon to the taste, and works alike in some effects.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Yes by'r lady in causing frowning, and crumpling faces.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: Not only so, but sharp air, and sharp lemons, do both cleanse from putrification, and keep from corruption.

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: But hot air works upon the body, as strong liquours upon the brain, for hot air distempers the body, as strong liquours do the mind.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Beshrew me, I have felt some airs as hot, and as burning, as brandywine.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: What wine is that?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: The wine of wine, the spirits of wine.

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: Indeed that wine, if you call it so, which is strong-waters, will work upon the body as soon as the hottest air, causing fevers and other malignant diseases.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: It seems that hot and burning air, works upon the spirits as much and as soon as the hottest liquours, and hot liquours upon the body as much as hot air, both causing fevers and frenzies.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: In truth, and I heard that Ayr is liquid, and so is drink, and drunkards, like frantic persons, will do mad tricks sometimes.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: And there are several sorts of air, as there are several sorts of drinks, some colder, some hotter, some moist, and some hath dry effects, and some air refreshes and quenches heat, other some dissipates and expels cold, some revives the spirits, and some enrages them, some corrupts bodies, and some preserves them.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: By my faith, I perceive air and drink have many good and bad qualities, but I had rather have good drink and bad air, than bad drink and good air, there is some substance in the one, but the other is like unto that which I have heard of but could never see, which is incorporality; for that which is not subject to my sight, I can hardly believe it is any thing.

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: Indeed very thin air is next unto nothing.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Tom. Adventurer is gone to be a soldier.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Yes, and he may chance to get a glorious fame.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: But particular fames are like particular creatures, some die and decay sooner than others, but few live to old Nestor's years, and some lie bedrid, and a great company are decrepit and lame, others are crooked and deformed from their birth, and some by evil fortune; and many are orphans, and abundance bastards and changelings; and though war makes the loudest noise in fame's palace, yet wit for the most part lives the longest therein; for wit is such a delightful company, and such pleasant pastime, as old father time takes great care to preserve it, lapping wit warm in the memory, and feeding it often with rehearsals.

div.head: Scene 15.
div.stage: Enter the lady examination, and the lady solitary.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: Come, come, you will never get you a real lover, if you delight so much in solitaries.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p:
I desire none: for real lovers do oftentimes prove unconstant,
whereas feigned lovers are as constant as the contemplator would have them, and as many as they would have; besides, a crowd or multitude of thoughts may rise up in the brain, and be as spectators of one single thought, which if the contemplator pleases may be a lover, and the rest of the spectators thoughts may censure of that single thought, as of his good parts, or bad, his virtues, or vices, some may praise, others dispraise, and the like; thus a contemplator can never want lovers, admirers, censurers, nor any other company, since the mind can present them with what thoughts they desire, not only the thoughts of men women and children, but of any other creatures that nature hath made; for why should not our spirits or soul delight and content us, without the real possession of outward good, as well as the spirits or soul doth torment us with a real evil? for why may not opinion, or fancy, as well and as much delight us, as opinion and fancy affright us, as they often do?

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: But an overstudious mind doth waste the body, for the thoughts feeds as much upon the body, as the body upon the meat we eat, and the body nourishes the thoughts as much as meat nourishes the body, and for the most part, as the body is effected so is the mind, for a distempered body makes a distempered mind, as a luxurious body makes an amorous mind; and a favour in the body makes the mind frantic, for the heat of a favour is like strong-water, it makes the spirits drunk, the thoughts dizzy, and the mind sick.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: Indeed the body and the mind do most commonly agree, as in monarchy the King and the subjects do, the subjects obeying the King, and the King commanding the subjects, yet sometimes the subjects compel the King, and sometimes the King forces the subjects, so sometimes the appetite compels the reason, at other times the reason forces the appetite to a moderation, and sometimes the humours of the body which are like the senseless commonalty, and the passions of the soul, which are as the nobles, oftentimes fall out, where sometimes the humours of the body usurp with an uproar the passions of the soul, and sometimes the passions overcome the humours by a wise policy; but whenas the kingdom of man is in peace, the imaginations in the head send down thoughts, as metal into the heart, wherein they are melted and minted into current coin, each thought as each piece having a several stamp, some is stamped with hate, some spite, others malice; some with jealousy, some hope, some with fear, some pity, some love, but that of love is of the highest value; but these coins serve for commerce and traffic in the body, from the authority of the mind or soul, whose stamp or image each piece bears.

div.head: Scene 16.
div.stage: Enter sir William admirer, and the lady peaceable.

sp.speaker: Admirer.
sp.p: Dear mistress how I love you!

sp.speaker: Peaceable.
sp.p: I wish I had merits worthy your affections.

sp.speaker: Admirer.
sp.p: You are all a man can wish in women kind, for you are young, fair, virtuous, witty and wise.

sp.speaker: Peaceable.
sp.p: Alas all youth hath more follies than years, whereas those that are old, have or ought to have more years than follies.

sp.speaker: Admirer.
sp.p: You might be thought old by your speech and actions, by reason you speak so experienced, and act with such prudence and discretion; wherefore I should judge you were instructed by those that are old, and knew much.

sp.speaker: Peaceable.
sp.p: Indeed my educators were aged, and my tutors, like as painters, drew with the pencil of the tongue, and the colours of sense, and the white of truth, on the platform of my brain, many figurate discourses for the understanding to view, but my understanding hath weak eyes.

sp.speaker: Admirer.
sp.p: Your understanding neither wants sight nor light, but the lady faction wants both, or else she had not been so uncivil to you as she was when I was with you last; were not you very choleric with her?

sp.speaker: Peaceable.
sp.p: I am of too melancholy a nature to be very choleric.

sp.speaker: Admirer.
sp.p: Why, are those that are melancholy never choleric?

sp.speaker: Peaceable.
sp.p: I cannot say never, but yet very seldom, by reason they want that heat which makes choler; for though the spirits of melancholy persons may be as quick as those that are choleric, yet they are not so fiery, for there is as much difference betwixt melancholy and choler, as freezing and burning, the one contracts into a sad silence, the other expulses in blows, and many extravagant actions, and angry words; but those persons which are seldom angry, as all melancholy persons are, who are of a patient, peaceable nature, yet when they are angry are very angry; to those persons that are naturally melancholy, that are seldom seen to be merry or to laugh, yet when they are merry, their mirth is ridiculous, and they will laugh extremely, as at nothing, or at any thing; so those that are naturally contemplative, when they do speak, they speak beyond all sense and reason, their speech flows like as a torrent, rough and forceable; thus we may perceive that extremes one way run into extremes another way.

sp.speaker: Admirer.
sp.p: I can truly witness that you are not apt to be angry, or at least not to appear angry; for I did wonder at your humble behaviour, civil answers, patient demeanours towards the lady faction.

sp.speaker: Peaceable.
sp.p: I may suffer an injury patiently when I cannot avoid it, but I will never injure myself in doing such actions, or speaking such words as are unbefitting, unworthy and base.

div.head: Scene 17.
div.stage: Enter the lady solitary, her governess a grave matron, and a gentleman as coming a journey.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Pray charge, thank this gentleman for his gifts and favours to me.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p:
Governess, let me tell you, that they do themselves a courtesy or
favour that do a courtesy or favour to another; and therefore there needs no thanks.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: But lady you ought to thank me, for coming out of my way so far as I have done to see you.

sp.speaker: Solitary
sp.p: No truly, for if you came out of your way to see me, if it were for affection, it is a duty to love, if for gratitude, it 'tis a duty to obligation, if for civility, it 'tis a duty to honour, if for charity, it 'tis a duty to heaven, and where a duty is due, the owner receives but his own when 'tis paid; wherefore it were a vain and extravagant civility, like unto madness, to give thanks for what is justly their own.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.p: I do confess lady I am yours, and therefore whatsoever I do, the best of my actions is due to you, and I repent for saying you ought to thank me for coming out of my way to see you, and I crave your pardon for my error, and ask forgiveness for my fault.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: I will forgive you, so I may be rid of you, for I love not company but solitariness.

div.head: Scene 18.
div.stage: Enter the lady Gadder, the lady Kindeling, and the lady Bridlehead.

sp.speaker: Bridlehead.
sp.p: Sir William admirer is like Argus, stuck full of eyes, but sir William's are the eyes of fair ladies that gaze upon him.

sp.speaker: Gadder.
sp.p: The truth is, when he is in the company of our sex, all the women gaze on him.

sp.speaker: Kindling.
sp.p: They may look if they please, and admire him, but I can assure them he loves and admires but one, which is the lady peaceable.

sp.speaker: Gadder.
sp.p: Why, is he in love with the lady peaceable?

sp.speaker: Kindling.
sp.p: So much as he is to be married to her within two or three days.

sp.speaker: Gadder.
sp.p: I thought he had loved the lady faction.

sp.speaker: Kindling.
sp.p: No, no, for he denies that ever he had any matrimonial love for her.

sp.speaker: Bridlehead.
sp.p: Will they make a public wedding?

sp.speaker: Kindling.
sp.p: No, 'tis said the wedding will be kept private.

div.head: Scene 19.
div.stage: Enter the lady censurer, the lady examination, and the lady solitary.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: Where have you been lady censurer?

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: Faith at court, amongst a company of ladies and their gallants.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: And what was their pastime?

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: Why singing, dancing, laughing, and jesting; but I have earned an angel amongst them.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: How prithee?

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: Although not by the sweat of my brows, yet by the expense of my spirits.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: Prithee tell.

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: Why the court ladies in a scornful jesting, for courtiers love to put persons out of countenance if they can, prayed me to sing an old song out of a new ballad, as knowing my voice fit for no better songs; but I told them, that if I did sing they should pay me for my pains; for there was never a blind beggar, or poor young wench, that sings at a door, but had something given them; they told me they would give me a penny, I answered, that when they sung to gentlemen or lady's guts, that they had a shilling at least given them, and unless they would give me twelve pence apiece, I would not sing; so they out of a laughing sport, borrowed a crown of the gentlemen to give me.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: O that's the court fashion, for the women to borrow of the men.

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: How should they live if they did not so? for in my conscience they could not have made up twelve pence amongst a dozen of them, not in money; for their clothes though costly and rich, yet are worn upon trust; but as I said, I was to sing them a song for my money; so I sung them an old song, the burden of the song, o women, women, monstrous women, what do you mean for to do? but because the song was against women, they would have had me given them their money back again, I told them no I would not, for it was lawful gain for me to keep it, since I gained it by an honest industry, and that those that made a bargain must stick to it; than they told me, that if I would sing them a good old song, they would give me another crown; I told them I would have the money in hand, for fear they should dislike my song when I had sung it, or at least to seem to dislike it, to save their money; so although they were loath, yet at last they borrowed another crown to give me, thinking it did disgrace me, in that my voice was fit for nothing but old ballads, for all their admirers, and courtly servants, or servants for courtship were with them; so then I sung them doctor Faustus that gave his soul away to the devil; for I knew conjurers and devils pleased women best.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: They fright women.

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p:
By your favour, all conjurers gain more by women's coming to them to know their fortunes, and for to find out losses, than they do by men; for where one man goeth to a conjurer or fortune-teller, their goeth a
hundred women; but as I have told you, I sung the song of doctor Faustus.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: For my part, I had rather hear a plain old song, than any Italian, or French love songs stuffed with trilloes.

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: That's strange, whenas in those harmonious songs the wisest poets, and skillfullest musicians, are joined to make up one song, and the most excellent voices are chosen to sing them.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: I know not, but I am sooner weary to hear a famous and artificial singer sing than they are themselves with singing, for I hate their quavers, demi, and semi quavers, their minims, crochets, and the like.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: The truth is, I have observed that when an old ballad is plainly sung, most hearers will listen with more delight, than to Italian and French singers, although they sing with art and skill.

sp.speaker: Solit.
sp.p: The most famous singer in these latter times I have heard in France, it was a woman, and an Italian sent for into France, where she was presented with very rich gifts for her rare singing, yet I durst ha laid my life for a wager, that there were more that could have taken more delight to hear an old ballad sung, which ballads are true storeys put into verses and set to a tune, than in all there italian and French love whining songs, and languishing tunes.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: Well, but what will you do with your gettings?

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: Faith I will go home and consider, and the next time I will tell you how I will employ my ten shillings.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: What makes you booted and spurred, are you going out of the town?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Yes faith, I am going to a wedding, switch and spur.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: What, art thou going to be married?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: No, I am not so hasty, for though I can spur to another man's wedding, I cannot be spurred to my own.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Whose wedding are you riding to?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: To sir William admirers, and the lady peaceable.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Faith their names and marriage do disagree; for never did husband after the first month admire his wife, nor a wife after two months live peaceably.

div.head: Scene 21.
div.stage: Enter the lady solitary, the lady examination, and the lady censurer.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: How have you employed the ten shillings got by singing?

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p:
I must tell you, I have been extremely troubled how to employ it, insomuch as my mind hath never been at rest; for their hath been such arguing and disputing and contradiction amongst my thoughts, as I did verily believe there would have been a mutiny in my head: for first I did resolve to put my ten shillings to pious uses, and then I thought to build some alms houses, as building one long room like a gallery, making in it several partitions, and the outward doors all alike; these houses, or rather partitioned rooms, for poor old and infirm persons, that could not work nor beg for their livelihood, to live in; but when I had well considered, that when I had built my alms houses, which is as I said one long room divided by partitions, I should have nothing left to maintain them, and they to have only houseroom, and have neither meat, drink, clothes, nor filing to feed them and to keep them from the injuries of the cold, having neither fires nor beds, I thought the parish wherein they were born, would better provide for them, so that instead of praying for me, they would curse me; besides I considered, that after I was dead, had I means to leave an allowance, yet when it came for the magistrates to choose, those that should be put in they would leave out, and choose idle young huswives, or foul sluts to dwell therein, such as those magistrates would visit sometimes, to see what they did want, so as I let that design pass; then I thought to build a church, and much were my thoughts concerned, whether the roof should be flat, or vaulted, or sloping; but after I had resolved how the roof should be, and where the belfry and quest-room, I was sore perplexed in my mind, as where or how to place the pulpit, whether at the East or West end, or at a corner in the church, or at one of the sides of the church close by the wall, but at last I resolved it should be placed in the midst of the church, in the very centre, that the voice of the minister might spread round to the circumference, so as all the congregation might hear him; but when I considered that when my church was built there was neither benefices, lands, nor tithes, nor any allowance for the minister, and that there was none that did or will preach merely for God's sake, but for gains sake, as to have a maintenance thereby, or some advancement therefrom, I desisted from that design; then I thought to build a bedlam, and be the keeper myself, but I considered that if any of the mad folks should get loose, they might kill me, besides they stink so horribly, and require so much cleansing, not being capable of keeping themselves clean, as I resolved not to go forward with that design; then I thought to build a free school, and I to be the chief tutoress myself, but when I remembered the confused noise the scholars make reading all at once, that neither I could hear nor they understand what they read, I thought it would be to no purpose, because the scholars would profit but little by their reading, and then I should be thought an ignorant tutoress; at last I thought to give my ten shillings to the poor beggars, but when I considered the alms that was given to beggars did more harm than good,
causing them to be idle and lazy, and encouraged them to go roving and roguing about, I changed my mind from that act, but finding I could not employ my ten shillings in any pious act, I thought to employ it in something to be remembered by, as for fame, whereupon I resolved to build a pyramid or cross, the pyramid to be vastly high, and the cross to be gloriously gilt, but then searing a rebellion, and knowing that in a rebellion a confused and superstitious rout, would certainly pull them down to the ground, and that when the cross or pyramid was down, I should be utterly forgottten, I desisted from that design; so finding as little employment for my money to any famous act as to any pious use, I resolved to employ it to my profit, so then I had a design to set up a shop of small wares, but when I considered how dead trading was, and how fast tradesmen did break, and instead of being enriched became poorer than when first they begun, for to set up a trade requires some stock, but when they break, they have not only lost their stock, but owe more than ever their stock was, so I went from that design; then I intended to buy me a parcel of land with my ten shillings, but hearing there was much danger in buying of land, for that many have mortgaged their lands to one, and sold them to another, or by an old deed that hath lain in some old trunk, desk, or box, which may be brought forth to claim the land again, so as I must be forced to go to law for my land I bought, which would cost me more than my lands, besides the infinite pains and trouble in following my law suit, and vexed with quirks, and quilters lawyers find to prolong the suit, or else I must let my land go, so lose it, finding this, I thought to put my money out to use, but then I considered that first I had only a piece of parchment for my money, besides, it is a general rule that few or none take up money at use, but those that are bankrupts, and when they had once got my money into their hands, I should neither get use or principal, for should I imprison them, I should be never the nearer to get my money, for where there is nothing to be had, says the old proverb, the King must lose his right; after this I intended to build a ship, and traffic with it on the seas, but then considering the various winds, the tempestuous storms, the rough seas, the lurking sands, the dreadful rocks, the gaping floods that might split and swallow my ship, and be drowned myself; I was resolved not to follow that design; then I thought to buy a place at court, but when I considered how I must cringe and creep, flatter, rail, and be factious, and at last the expenses at court would be more than the profit of my place, by which I should become a beggar, or at least a shark, I left off that design; but after all these considerations I concluded with myself that the most profitablest way to employ my ten shillings was to build a bawdy house, for I was sure that as soon as ever it was built customers would resort thereunto; besides it was the most certain gain that was, without any expenses, whereas all other trades or professions require means or stocks to begin with, whereas in these professions or trade the poorest may set up without borrowing or begging, for a stock to begin with; neither can alterations of times ruin it, for in all times whether peace or wars, and in all nations, this trade never fails, whereunto if you please to come ladies, you shall be very welcome.

sp.speaker: Solitary.
sp.p: It will not agree with my humour, for I love solitariness, and there will be too much company.

sp.speaker: Censurer.
sp.p: There may be a great resort, but their conversation is by single couples.

sp.speaker: Examination.
sp.p: You are a wag lady censurer.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: If I were to choose a wife, I would choose the lady solitary.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: Because those that are solitary love not much company, and being alone love not much noise, and loving no noise, love silence, and loving silence, love not to talk, so as in having of her, I shall have a solitary, peaceable, quiet, silent wife.

sp.speaker: 3 gent.
sp.p: And if I were to choose, I would choose the lady censurer, for she would let nothing pass her judgement: for she will give her opinion of all things, persons, and actions; so in having her to my wife, I should have a general intelligencer, or at least her opinion of all things.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: But if her judgement were not good, her opinion would be erroneous.

sp.speaker: 3 gent.
sp.p: I care not, it would serve to pass an idle time with.

sp.speaker: 4 gent.
sp.p: And if I might choose, I would choose the lady examination for a wife.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: 4 gent.
sp.p: Because she knows most humours and passages of everybody , and their affairs, so by her I should be entertained with news from all places, as of all actions done, opinions held, words spoke, or thoughts thought.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: I would I could have my wish as easily, as you might have your choice.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.p: What would you wish?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.p: I would wish to be unmarried, for if I were, I would never be troubled with a wife again; but let me advise you, for I love to have married companions, that you three should go a-wooing to those three ladies, they cannot nor will not deny your suit, being all three of you rich, young and handsome.

sp.speaker: All three.
sp.p: We will take your counsel.
